{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3421571,"name":"Falon Clark","username":"Tatiman-Dev","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tatiman-dev/{size}/236095_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-07T07:03:31.712Z","cooked":"

Hello! My name is Falon and I’m one of the software leads on 2537. Here on 2537 we use Kotlin, and I’d like to make this more accessible to other teams. One of the biggest (and most valid) arguments against Kotlin is the lack of resources. This is 100% accurate, as the only real resources are other team’s repositories, and talking to people about it. At the moment the WPILib wiki contains no Kotlin example code, and I’d like to work on changing that.

So here is my proposal, and/or call to arms. I’d like to put together a group of people who are passionate (or just simply interested) in bringing better Kotlin resources to FRC, and work together to build up said resources. Whether it’s trying to get things pulled into WPILib and the WPILib wiki (which is certainly preferred), or maintaining our own documentation on it.

I really have no idea if this is going to reach anybody, but if you’re interested please reach out either through commenting here, or emailing me at falon@team2537.com.

It’s super cool that you are looking to make a Kotlin resource!

I will say that making technical resources for FRC that are good is hard, but I don’t want to discourage you from doing it since I’m all about raising the floor and making FRC more accessible.

I started a pretty in-depth technical project that has made some pretty decent resources for robot design. If you are curious about how that project got started and the story behind it (and why it got so far), feel free to DM me (with a mentor for ypp) and I can give some advice/share my story in a call or something.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-09-09T14:21:43.177Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":157,"readers_count":156,"score":36.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470872,"topic_slug":"calling-all-frc-kotlin-people","display_username":"Falon Clark","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":19820,"username":"ArchdukeTim","name":"Tim Winters","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/archduketim/{size}/256125_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57393,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"The Kotlin Guy"},"post_url":"/t/calling-all-frc-kotlin-people/470872/15","custom_user_title":"The Kotlin Guy","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3422033,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-09T14:46:11.400Z","cooked":"

At this time, we won’t be able to accept Kotlin examples into the WPILib docs. There are two primary concerns: (1) having examples for a language in the official documentation/distribution implies that teams will receive support in that language from CSAs at events, and (2) it further increases the long-term maintenance burden on the team at a time when we’re already struggling to maintain the existing documentation and examples across the 3 languages we already have (and are asking for help).

While there’s clearly interest in the community in Kotlin, note it took Python over 10 years showing steady growth (and dedication to long-term maintenance, as well as sustained communication from the community that there was demand for the language) before it became official and was integrated into the WPILib docs.

Some next steps to consider (this applies not only to Kotlin, but for any other language people want to add):

  • Continue to develop a community of FRC Kotlin users, especially including mentors who will be dedicated for the longer term (note that high school and college students tend to be involved only for a few years before a major life change disrupts their involvement).
  • Develop an independent documentation resource site dedicated to Kotlin (how to get started with it, what the resources are, if there’s additional library overlays needed, what the differences from Java are, how to make sure usage reporting shows up, etc). This should not be a fork of the WPILib docs, but rather docs dedicated to Kotlin specifics.
  • In terms of examples, one possible crazy idea: it might be possible via a Chrome extension or similar to inject Kotlin versions of examples into the WPILib docs. How this is different than having them integrated is that it takes a clear manual step from a user to add them, so it’s clear that it’s not an officially supported language.

In terms of examples, one possible crazy idea: it might be possible via a Chrome extension or similar to inject Kotlin versions of examples into the WPILib docs. How this is different than having them integrated is that it takes a clear manual step from a user to add them, so it’s clear that it’s not an officially supported language.

I really like this idea as an intermediate step.
